history.content:
I found Math110 incredibly useful for 127 + 189. 

54 teaches you the computational aspect of linear algebra, but I found 127 + 189 expected me to be comfortable solely writing in linear algebra proofs (instead of doing say simple matrix computation), and Math110 was the "bridge" between the computation of 54 and the proofs of 127+189. 

Also, if you love linear algebra, Math110 is a fun class to take in of itself - you learn so beyond what 54 teaches you and I found this fascinating. 

HOWEVER, the advice above comes with the caveat of that I never took EE16a/b. EE16a/b + 70 is supposed to teach you not only the computational knowledge of linear algebra you need for 127 +189, but also the proof writing skills necessary for upper division math-focused courses (which is why those classes, not math110, are prereqs for 127 +189) . Having not taken ee16a/b, I cannot say for sure whether its enough (and I think its tailored to each individual student). From my personal experience, I didn't leave 70 with the proof writing skills I needed for upper divs (my own fault), so Math110 was the class that taught me the abstract proof based thinking I needed in other upper divs. It's dependent on each person's own experience though!

After taking EE16A/B, how useful is Math 110 if I plan on taking EECS 127 and CS 189? From my understanding Math 110 is more abstract and is focused more on teaching proofwriting and building maturity rather than linear algebra techniques beyond EE16A/B or Math 54 level, and I'm wondering whether I can do well in EECS 127 and CS 189 without the stronger linear algebra foundation provided by Math 110. If it matters I'm also aiming for research in ML.
history.subject: Math 110 for EECS 127 and CS 189
